t: Proverbs 22
A*pn good name is more desirable than great riches; to*ld be esteemed is better than silver or gold.
Rich*pn and poor have this in common: The*ld Lord*s is the Maker of them all.
The*pn prudent see danger and take refuge, but*ld the simple keep going and pay the penalty.
Humility*pn is the fear of the Lord;*s its*ld wages are riches and honor and life.
In*pn the paths of the wicked are snares and pitfalls, but*ld those who would preserve their life stay far from them.
Start*pn children off on the way they should go, and*ld even when they are old they will not turn from it.
The*pn rich rule over the poor, and*ld the borrower is slave to the lender.
Whoever*pn sows injustice reaps calamity, and*ld the rod they wield in fury will be broken.
The*pn generous will themselves be blessed, for*ld they share their food with the poor.
Drive*pn out the mocker, and out goes strife; quarrels*ld and insults are ended.
One*pn who loves a pure heart and who speaks with grace will*ld have the king for a friend.
The*pn eyes of the Lord*s keep watch over knowledge, but*ld he frustrates the words of the unfaithful.
The*pn sluggard says, “There’s a lion outside! I’ll*ld be killed in the public square!”
The*pn mouth of an adulterous woman is a deep pit; a*ld man who is under the Lord’s*s wrath falls into it.
Folly*pn is bound up in the heart of a child, but*ld the rod of discipline will drive it far away.
One*pn who oppresses the poor to increase his wealth and*ld one who gives gifts to the rich—both come to poverty.
Thirty Sayings of the Wise
Saying 1
Pay*pn attention and turn your ear to the sayings of the wise; apply*ld your heart to what I teach,
for*ln it is pleasing when you keep them in your heart and*ld have all of them ready on your lips.
So*ln that your trust may be in the Lord,*s I*ld teach you today, even you.
Have*ln I not written thirty sayings for you, sayings*ld of counsel and knowledge,
teaching*ln you to be honest and to speak the truth, so*ld that you bring back truthful reports to*ld those you serve?
Saying 2
Do*pn not exploit the poor because they are poor and*ld do not crush the needy in court,
for*ln the Lord*s will take up their case and*ld will exact life for life.
Saying 3
Do*pn not make friends with a hot-tempered person, do*ld not associate with one easily angered,
or*ln you may learn their ways and*ld get yourself ensnared.
Saying 4
Do*pn not be one who shakes hands in pledge or*ld puts up security for debts;
if*ln you lack the means to pay, your*ld very bed will be snatched from under you.
Saying 5
Do*pn not move an ancient boundary stone set*ld up by your ancestors.
Saying 6
Do*pn you see someone skilled in their work? They*ld will serve before kings; they*ld will not serve before officials of low rank.
